title: Can a debtor discharge (in Chapter 13) a debt from a judgment against him for conversion? The judgment is from a civil court.
question: Some more info: He filed a chapter 7 and I did an Adversary Proceeding and won that too.
answers: My colleagues have given you accurate, correct advice. Its up to you to follow it and timely file a proof of claim.

If you won an adversary proceeding in the Chapter 7 case, and if the court ruled that the claim for conversion could not be discharged under 11 U.S.C. Section 523 (a) (4), then this debt cannot be discharged in the Chapter 13 case as well. Just make sure you timely file a proof of claim before the bar date in the Chapter 13 case. You may also want to take your adversary proceeding order and the Chapter 13 hearing notice in for review by a local bankruptcy attorney.

If you have a debt that has been declared non dischargeable 523(a) in bankruptcy then the chapter 13 plan must pay your non dischargeable debt. In a chapter 13 you must file a proof of claim before the claims deadline. If the plan treatment is not correct then you must object to the plan.
You may want to consult with a knowledgeable bankruptcy attorney to make sure you collect on the debt that is due you.
